spell.name: Curse of the Ashen Tongue (HB) [2024]
spell.range: same place of existence as caster
spell.duration: Indefinitely, Caster dies, or lifting condition is met
spell.text:
You touch a creature, which must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw or become cursed for the duration. You curse a creature's words to twist and bend in meaning, failing to ally with its intentions. When attempting to make a Deception, Intimidation or Persuasion check, the creature must roll a d20. On a result of 1 to 10, it is forced to use another skill from amongst the three (chosen by the Storyteller) in place of its initial choice.
Components. The spell requires a body part, lock of hair, bit of nail, or the like that belongs to the creature. The component is consumed in the casting process. At the Storyteller's discretion, if the creature has wronged you greatly in the past, you may use your seething hatred towards it as the spell's sole component.
Source: Zamanora: Ballad of the Witch p. 179 (Homebrew)

spell.name: Curse of Vampirism (HB) [2024]
spell.range: same place of existence as caster
spell.duration: Indefinitely, Caster dies, or lifting condition is met
spell.text:
You curse a Humanoid with restless death. The target's heart becomes frail and vulnerable. The next time the target drops to 0 Hit Points it dies outright, without rolling Death Saving Throws. If the target's body is not buried and bestowed proper funeral rites until the next dawn, it rises as an Umpyr.
Neonate. On the first night, the creature rises with a ravenous hunger. Its eyes darken, its reflection grows faint, and its blackened heart begins to beat anew. The creature's alignment shifts one step towards evil, as its morals grow insignificant when compared to the hunger. Its Strength, Dexterity, and Constitution scores each become 14, unless already higher. In addition, it gains one of the Vampire Weaknesses described in the Vampire statblock, at random. Henceforth, the cursed creature needs to consume some part of a living Humanoid, such as the blood, liver, or soul, in order to survive. If it refuses to feed, it suffers one level of Exhaustion at dawn, which lasts until it feeds or dies.
Fledgling. After the creature feeds for the first time, the Curse strengthens. Its alignment shifts one step towards evil, as its hunger becomes an all-encompassing torture, leaving room for little else. Its Strength, Dexterity, and Constitution scores each become 16, unless already higher, and it gains one additional Vampire Weakness. In addition, the cursed creature becomes resistant to Necrotic damage and gains Darkvision out to 120ft. The cursed creature's type becomes Undead (Umpyr). It doesn't need to eat, drink, breathe, or sleep, and magic can't put it to sleep. It can finish a Long Rest in 4 hours if it spends those hours in an inactive, motionless state, during which it retains consciousness.
Umpyr. The second night the cursed creature feeds, its Curse latches on forever. Its Strength, Dexterity, and Constitution scores each become 18, unless already higher, and it gains the final two Vampire Weaknesses. The creature also gains the Vampire's Speeds, Traits, and Actions. It is proficient with the form's natural attacks, such as its bite or grave strike, which deal damage as shown in its statistics. From now on, in order to complete a Long Rest, the cursed creature must be lying on soil from the place where it first rose; otherwise it does not gain the benefits of resting. Only a Wish or its specific lifting conditions can undo the Curse at this point.
Source: Zamanora: Ballad of the Witch p. 184 (Homebrew)

spell.name: Curse of Therianthropy (HB) [2024]
spell.range: same place of existence as caster
spell.duration: Indefinitely, Caster dies, or lifting condition is met
spell.text:
You curse a Humanoid that has committed inhuman acts to assume a form befitting their heinous deeds. Over the next 7 days, the target transforms into a werekin befitting their circumstances (from the options in the Monster Manual). Therianthropic transformations typically reflect the nature of the target's actions. For example, ruthless anger may be punished with a Werewolf form, gluttony with that of a Wereboar, and avarice with the form of the Wererat.
The Mark. After the cursed creature finishes its first Long Rest, it starts growing visible alterations to its physical form, such as patches of fur, claws, or fangs. It also begins to develop increased aggression and mood swings. These grant the target Disadvantage on Charisma (Persuasion) and Charisma (Deception) checks against Humanoids.
The Hunger. By the third day, the cursed creature feels an unrelenting craving for raw flesh. At the end of each Long Rest, it must succeed on a DC 15 Wisdom saving throw or gain one level of Exhaustion unless it has consumed raw meat during the day.
The Beast Without. When the moon rises on the night of the 7th day, the target must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw against the Curse's spell save DC. On a success, the beast is contained until the next full moon, until the target is bloodied, or until it kills a Humanoid, whereupon the target repeats its saving throw. On a failure, the target succumbs to the Curse, assuming the hybrid form of its therianthropic variant. It loses control of itself until the next dawn, while the beast tries to sate its needs. The target can repeat the saving throw each subsequent night, suppressing the Curse on a success, as described above. If the moon is full, this saving throw is made with Disadvantage.
Mortal No More. Once the creature has failed five saving throws in this way (not necessarily consecutively), it loses itself to the Curse entirely. Its type changes to Monstrosity (Lycanthrope), and its mind regresses to that of an agitated beast, the creature's Intelligence, Wisdom and Charisma scores replaced by those of the therianthrope's animal form. The creature remains in the hybrid form indefinitely, losing the ability to turn back. Only a Wish or its specific lifting conditions can undo the Curse at this point.
Bestial Form. A creature cursed with therianthropy, that has succeeded on a saving throw made to suppress or control its transformation at least once, can willingly assume the bestial or hybrid form of its variant, as described in the monster's Shape-Shift trait. When it does so, it gains the following traits:
• The creature's Strength, Dexterity and Constitution scores are replaced by those of the therianthrope, unless these scores are already higher.
• The creature gains the therianthrope's speeds, traits, and the Actions of its beast or hybrid form.
• The character is proficient with the form's natural attacks, such as its bite or claws, which deal damage as shown in its statistics.
• A therianthrope can't speak while in animal form.
When the creature reduces a Humanoid to 0 Hit Points while in these forms, it must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw or suffer the effects of succumbing to the Curse, as described above.
Source: Zamanora: Ballad of the Witch p. 186 (Homebrew)
